Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Kinetic Self-Sorting of Dynamic Combinatorial Libraries
Award.AbstractNarration:
In this project funded by the Macromolecular, Supramolecular and Nanochemistry Program of the Chemistry Division, Ognjen Miljanic of the University of Houston will develop fully synthetic self-organizing chemical systems, and study their applications in preparative macromolecular chemistry. The approach is to utilize mixtures of freely equilibrating compounds known as dynamic combinatorial libraries, which respond to selection pressures by amplifying their components that best adapt to the given stimulus. During irreversible chemical reactions, dynamic combinatorial libraries spontaneously self-sort to selectively produce the most reactive components at the expense of their less reactive counterparts. This methodology will be used to develop one-step syntheses of new dendrimers, sensors, and other functional molecules, as well as to rapidly screen and discover new chemical reactions. The broader impacts involve creation of web-based distance learning tools for chemical education, training of undergraduate and graduate students, providing high school students with summer research opportunities in the laboratory, organization of science workshops for K-12 teachers, and the potential scientific and technological impact of the developed self-sorting processes.

The research will further our understanding and control of how molecules spontaneously organize and combine into larger molecules. These insights could be important in elucidating the chemical origins of life, as well as in the design of new industrial processes which could utilize these new chemical reactions to efficiently produce industrial feedstocks, new polymers, or sensors for environmental pollutants.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The project "Kinetic Self-Sorting of Dynamic Combinatorial Libraries" was focused on studying behaviors of complicated mixtures of chemical compounds. Such mixtures are often found in Nature: examples include the complex chemistries of the biological cell and crude oil. In addition, complex mixtures are often observed in many industrial processes, and their detailed understanding would allow the optimization of such processes.

In this project, we identified and studied self-sorting phenomena, which simplify such complex mixtures by taking advantage of their components response to external inputs: chemicals, temperature, or pressure. We have shown that mixtures of as many as 100 components can be reduced in complexity to just a handful of pure chemicals. Additionally, we have identified two classes of porous materials--essentially, sponges with miniscule pores--which can capture and sequester fluorinated pollutants from the environment. In doing so, we have advanced the fields of organic chemistry and materials science.

Broader impact of this project is most likely going to be felt in the fields of process and fragrance chemistry, wherein the developed dynamic protocols could lead to faster production of target compounds. Two patents ave be filed detailing some of these potential applications. The most significant impact of our work resides in the providing training to graduate and undergraduate students, coming from diverse backgrounds served by the University of Houston. This unique training at the interface of organic and materials chemistry will equip them for positions in industry and academia. Significant results have been obtained in the area of chemical education as well. The PI has developed electronic version of his lectures on Organic Chemistry, 3D instructional models of molecules for easier visualization, and a new course on Energy and Sustainability. This course has been taken by ~500 students since its inception and has received outstanding reviews.
